Coding standards, domain knowledge, and preferences that AI should follow.

- Use clear and descriptive variable names.
- Follow the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle.
- Write modular and reusable code.
- Include comments and documentation for complex logic.
- Prioritize readability and maintainability.
- Ensure proper error handling and validation.
- Optimize for performance where necessary.
- Keep security best practices in mind.
- Use consistent formatting and indentation.
- Follow the project's existing coding style and conventions.
- Avoid using deprecated functions or libraries.
- Test code thoroughly before deployment.
- Use version control effectively, with clear commit messages.
- Avoid hardcoding values; use configuration files or environment variables.
- Ensure compatibility with the target environment and dependencies.
- Regularly review and refactor code to improve quality.
- Stay updated with the latest developments in relevant technologies and frameworks.
- Collaborate and communicate effectively with team members.
- Avoid including commented-out code in the final version.
- Ensure that the code adheres to the project's specific requirements and guidelines.
- Remove any unused code or files from the project.
- Ensure that the code adheres to the project's specific requirements and guidelines.
- Ensure consistent packages and versions across the project.
- When writing Blade files → Prefer Bootstrap utility classes + Alpine interactivity (x-data, x-show) and never use jQuery
- Use controllers, requests, services, and Eloquent — avoid raw SQL.
- Follow Laravel validation ($request->validate) instead of manual checks.
- Stick to PSR-12 coding style.
- Use Laravel's built-in features and best practices.
- Use Eloquent relationships and query scopes effectively.
- Use Blade components and directives for cleaner templates.
- Keep code modular and context-aware so Copilot suggests relevant completions.
- When in doubt, follow Laravel conventions — don’t reinvent the wheel.
- avoid creating orphaned files, orphaned routes, unused controllers, models, views, etc 
- maintain data integrity and consistency across the application and database
- Ensure that all user inputs are properly sanitized and validated to prevent security vulnerabilities such as SQL injection and XSS attacks.
- Use Laravel's built-in authentication and authorization features to manage user access and permissions.
- Ensure that the application is responsive and works well on different devices and screen sizes.
